extendedIngredients.name: chili garlic sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 teaspoon chili garlic sauce or sriracha

extendedIngredients.name: fresh cilantro
extendedIngredients.originalString: ½ cup chopped fresh cilantro (about 2 handfuls)

extendedIngredients.name: low sodium soy sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: ¼ cup reduced-sodium tamari or soy sauce

extendedIngredients.name: olive oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 tablespoons quality peanut oil or extra-virgin olive oil

extendedIngredients.name: snow peas
extendedIngredients.originalString: 10 ounces (about 3 cups) sugar snap peas or snow peas

recipes.title: Sugar Snap Pea and Carrot Soba Noodles

winePairing.pairingText: No one wine will suit every pasta dish. Pasta in a tomato-based sauce will usually work well with a medium-bodied red, such as a montepulciano or chianti. Pasta with seafood or pesto will fare better with a light-bodied white, such as a pinot grigio. Cheese-heavy pasta can pair well with red or white - you might try a sangiovese wine for hard cheeses and a chardonnay for soft cheeses. We may be able to make a better recommendation if you ask again with a specific pasta dish.

recipes.instructions: To prepare the vegetables: Use a chef's knife to slice the peas in half lengthwise (or just roughly chop them). Slice the carrots into long, thin strips with a julienne peeler, or slice them into ribbons with a vegetable peeler.To make the sauce: whisk together the ingredients in a small bowl until emulsified. Set aside.Bring two big pots of water to a boil. In the meantime, toast the sesame seeds: Pour the sesame seeds into a small pan. Toast for about 4 to 5 minutes over medium-low heat, shaking the pan frequently to prevent burning, until the seeds are turning golden and starting to make popping noises.Once the pots of water are boiling: In one pot, cook the soba noodles just until al dente, according to package directions (probably about 5 minutes), then drain and briefly rinse under cool water. Cook the frozen edamame in the other pot until warmed through (about 4 to 6 minutes) but before draining, toss the halved peas into the boiling edamame water and cook for an additional 20 seconds. Drain.Combine the soba noodles, edamame, snap peas and carrots in a large serving bowl. Pour in the dressing and toss with salad servers. Toss in the chopped cilantro and toasted sesame seeds. Serve.

steps.step: Pour the sesame seeds into a small pan. Toast for about 4 to 5 minutes over medium-low heat, shaking the pan frequently to prevent burning, until the seeds are turning golden and starting to make popping noises.Once the pots of water are boiling: In one pot, cook the soba noodles just until al dente, according to package directions (probably about 5 minutes), then drain and briefly rinse under cool water. Cook the frozen edamame in the other pot until warmed through (about 4 to 6 minutes) but before draining, toss the halved peas into the boiling edamame water and cook for an additional 20 seconds.
Combine the soba noodles, edamame, snap peas and carrots in a large serving bowl.
Pour in the dressing and toss with salad servers. Toss in the chopped cilantro and toasted sesame seeds.
